News
Letter
Madison, Wis.
Mrs. W. W. Argow, Editor
OCTOBER 1, 1954
NUMBER 6
One Dollar Brings You
Membership in ACBB
Radio and TV are the source of much of
our information and entertainment. They
are educators and creators of public opin¬
ion. They enter our homes and influence
our way of life. As individual citizens we
have little say about what is provided by
these powerful media. We can only choose
from what is available, or do without. As
members of the American Council for Bet¬
ter Broadcasts, however, we become part
of a national organization dedicated and
actively working to retain the good pro¬
grams now on the air and through cooper¬
ative efforts and Look-Listen projects, to
secure the best possible programs in all lines
for American viewers and listeners.
October has been designated by ACBB
as individual membership month and we
hope that new members and local groups
along with renewals and state and national
organizations will swell membership and
increase the effectiveness of the Look-Listen
project and the numerous other activities of
ACBB.
A one-dollar membership in ACBB
makes you a part of the national organi¬
zation, brings you five issues of the ACBB
Newsletter, gives you the privilege of par¬
ticipating in the 1954-55 Look-Listen pro¬
ject. gives your group the compiled results
of that project and provides you with the
opportunity of making your voice heard in
the use and development of radio and TV.
When a local group joins ($1.00-$3.00, de¬
pending on number of members) and ten
of its individual members, ACBB offers to
provide the cards free as well as the other
material for the Look-Listen project. Thirty
persons monitoring and evaluating radio and
television, discussing their findings and
comparing them with those of others across
the nation, can be real forces for better
radio-TV and for understanding and respect
between broadcaster, radio-TV stations and
the public.
There is no time like the present to send
a dollar for membership in the American
Council for Better Broadcasts, 423 N. Pinck¬
ney St., Madison, Wisconsin, and to encour¬
age your neighbors and organizations to
join. Also, what could be a better gift to
friends and relatives than a membership
in ACBB? Increased membership in this or¬
ganization will mean increased value to
each member as well as the public. The cost
is within the reach of everyone. Let us

Music
Unwise To Spurn Classics
From Variety we quote part of an arti¬
cle:
"It should have become apparent to
WNBC by this time that its ‘Music through
the Night’ in its original format is certain¬
ly the NBC flagship’s best bet for the early
morning hours. Yet the station has per¬
sisted in juggling (it) so as to make it lose
the identity that it established a couple of
years back when the all-classical music
format had the whole industry talking . . .
Latest innovation is use of pop music in
the first hour (12-1 a.m.) with classical
music the rest of the way.’’
Two instances are cited of other stations
moving in with classical music where NBC
had substituted popular fare; the question
is then asked: “Then why the pops, just at
the hour when classical music would be
most effective?”
Classics Preferred
CBS has found that classical music is
preferred on its “Music ’Til Dawn” all-
night show. Listeners were polled by a
“Request Week” in Boston, Washington,
New York, Chicago, Detroit, and San
Francisco. Out of 4000 replies, 2700 re¬
quested classical selections: 1,070, semi-
classical; and 600, popular. Men sent in
more than half of the requests.

AMERICAN COUNCIL FOR
BETTER BROADCASTS
a coordinating organization
PURPOSE:
1. to stimulate the broadcasting of good
radio and television programs;
2. to study in order to arrive at stand¬
ards for judging programs;
3. to encourage radio and television sta¬
tions in fulfilling their obligations to
“serve the public interest, convenience and
necessity.”
KEYNOTE: APPRECIATION of the good,
and MORE DEFINITE APPRAISAL of
all.
MEANS OF EXPRESSION: a project of
evaluating programs in which all can join
—this year the Look-Listen Project,
described in column 1.
NEWS TO MEMBERS: News of radio-
TV and of what other listeners are doing
and can do—the NEWSLETTER, with
FIVE issues this first year.
MEMBERSHIP is open to organizations
and individuals who are not professionally
engaged in radio-TV or programming for
them.
DUES are nominal: individuals, $1.00; Lo¬
cal groups of fewer than fifty, $1.00; 50-
200, $2.00; over 200, $3.00. State groups,
$10.00. National groups, $25.00.
Send checks direct to Council head¬
quarters, 423 N. Pinckney, Madison, Wis.
